questions.question: Which property best describes all solids?

answers.content: They keep a fixed shape
answers.explanation: Solids have a definite, fixed shape that does not depend on their container.

answers.content: They flow to fill the bottom of a container
answers.explanation: This is a property of liquids, not solids.

answers.content: They can be compressed easily
answers.explanation: Gases can be compressed easily; solids generally cannot.

answers.content: They are invisible to the eye
answers.explanation: Visibility is not a defining property of solids.

questions.question: In the syringe investigation, which state of matter was easily compressed?

answers.content: Solid
answers.explanation: The sand (solid) did not compress.

answers.content: Liquid
answers.explanation: The water (liquid) did not compress.

answers.content: Gas
answers.explanation: Air (gas) compressed when pressure was applied.

answers.content: Both solid and liquid
answers.explanation: Neither solids nor liquids compressed in the investigation.

questions.question: Which group of objects could be classified together because they are flexible?

answers.content: Coins, aluminium foil, metal spoon
answers.explanation: These objects are metallic but not all are flexible.

answers.content: Pipe cleaners, Blu Tack, eraser
answers.explanation: All three items can be bent or shaped—they are flexible.

answers.content: Drinking glass, window pane, glass bottle
answers.explanation: These are all made of glass, not chosen for flexibility.

answers.content: Stop sign, post box, tomato
answers.explanation: These do not share the property of flexibility.

questions.question: Define the term ‘property’ in the context of matter and give TWO different properties scientists use to classify substances.

answers.content: A property is any observable characteristic of a substance, such as appearance or behaviour. Examples include colour, hardness, flexibility, mass, state (solid/liquid/gas), compressibility.

questions.question: Why can a kitchen sponge be squeezed even though it is mostly a solid material?

answers.content: A sponge contains many tiny pockets of air (a gas) within the solid network. When you press it, the air pockets are compressed, so the sponge as a whole can be squeezed.

questions.question: Which statement about plasma is TRUE?

answers.content: Plasma forms when a solid melts.
answers.explanation: Melting produces a liquid, not plasma.

answers.content: Plasma can conduct electricity and is affected by magnetic fields.
answers.explanation: These are key properties that distinguish plasma from ordinary gases.

answers.content: There is very little plasma in the universe compared with solids.
answers.explanation: Scientists believe plasma is the most abundant state of matter in the universe.

answers.content: Plasma has a fixed volume like a liquid.
answers.explanation: Plasma, like gases, does not have a fixed volume.

questions.question: Draw particle diagrams for a solid and a gas. Label each diagram with TWO properties that explain why the particles are arranged that way.

answers.content: Expected drawing: 1) Solid – particles closely packed in a fixed, orderly arrangement. Labels could include ‘fixed shape’ and ‘not easily compressed’. 2) Gas – particles far apart and randomly arranged. Labels could include ‘fills container’ and ‘compressible’.

questions.question: Which property of gases is demonstrated when the air inside a bike pump can be squeezed into a smaller space?

answers.content: Gases can be compressed.
answers.explanation: Pushing the handle forces the same amount of air into a smaller volume, showing compressibility.

answers.content: Gases have mass.
Gases take the shape of their container.
Gases flow from place to place.

questions.question: During Investigation 2 (Waterproof Paper), the tissue stayed dry when the cup was lowered straight down. What is the BEST explanation?

answers.content: Air trapped in the cup takes up space and keeps water out.
answers.explanation: The trapped air acts as a barrier because gases occupy space.

answers.content: Water cannot rise inside clear plastic cups.
The tissue is waterproof.
Water is repelled by nitrogen in the air.

questions.question: Name the gas that is produced when vinegar reacts with baking soda in Investigation 3 (Gas Bag).

answers.content: Carbon dioxide (CO₂)
answers.explanation: The chemical reaction between acetic acid and sodium bicarbonate releases carbon dioxide gas, inflating the bag.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a property of gases?

answers.content: Gases have a fixed shape.
answers.explanation: Unlike solids, gases do not keep a fixed shape; they fill the shape of their container.

answers.content: Gases have mass.
Gases can flow.
Gases have volume.

questions.question: Why can you smell a cake baking in the kitchen from your bedroom?

answers.content: Gases flow from one place to another, carrying the smell through the air.
answers.explanation: Odour molecules in the air move throughout the house because gases can flow.

answers.content: Heat travels faster than smell.
Solids turn into gases instantly.
Sound waves carry the smell.

questions.question: Explain why a helium-filled balloon rises in air.

answers.content: Helium is less dense (lighter) than the surrounding air, so the balloon experiences an upward buoyant force and rises.
answers.explanation: Objects containing gas that is less dense than air displace heavier air and float upward.

questions.question:
Draw and clearly label the Gas Bag investigation. Your diagram should show:
• the vinegar, baking soda and bag before sealing
• the production of carbon dioxide gas
• how the gas changes the shape/volume of the bag.

answers.content: Student supplies labelled drawing.
answers.explanation: A complete diagram will show the reactants, arrows or bubbles indicating CO₂ production, and the inflated bag demonstrating gas volume.

questions.question: Which statement about aerogel, featured in Activity 7, is TRUE?

answers.content: Aerogel is about 99 % gas and is an excellent thermal insulator.
answers.explanation: Its structure is mostly trapped gas, making it lightweight and very good at preventing heat transfer.

answers.content: Aerogel is a dense metal that conducts heat well.
Aerogel is widely used because it is inexpensive.
Aerogel is made entirely of liquid nitrogen.

questions.question: Which definition BEST describes the term “viscosity”?

answers.content: The temperature at which a substance melts.
The amount of space a substance occupies.
A measure of how quickly a liquid flows.
answers.explanation: Viscosity refers to the “runniness” of a liquid—how easily it flows.

answers.content: The mass of a substance per unit volume.

questions.question: During the ‘Runny Honey’ race, which ONE of the following variables MUST be kept the SAME to ensure a fair test?

answers.content: Type of liquid.
Amount of liquid placed at the start line.
answers.explanation: Only the amount, plate, distance and angle should stay the same. The liquid type is the variable that is changed.

answers.content: Angle of the tray for honey and a different angle for shampoo.
Time allowed for each liquid to finish the race.

questions.question: Squeezy Vegemite introduced in 2020 must have ________ viscosity compared with regular jar Vegemite.

answers.content: higher
lower
answers.explanation: To flow out of a squeeze bottle Vegemite must be thinner → lower viscosity.

answers.content: the same
zero

questions.question: Which statement about the University of Queensland Pitch-Drop experiment is CORRECT?

answers.content: It proves pitch is a solid because it never drips.
It demonstrates that very viscous liquids can appear solid but still flow.
answers.explanation: The pitch eventually forms drops, showing it is an extremely viscous liquid.

answers.content: It measures the boiling point of pitch.
It lasts one school term.

questions.question: Which of the following liquids would you PREDICT to have the LOWEST viscosity?

answers.content: Honey
Tomato sauce
Water
answers.explanation: Water flows fastest and therefore has the lowest viscosity.

answers.content: Custard

questions.question: Describe ONE challenge you or your partner faced while timing the liquids during the viscosity race and suggest a way to improve the method next time.

answers.content: Sample answer: We found it hard to start and stop the stopwatch at exactly the right moment. Next time we would record a slow-motion video of the run and use the timecode so our measurements are more accurate.
answers.explanation: Any reasonable description of a procedural difficulty and a realistic improvement earns full marks.

questions.question: Complete the table by filling in ONE control variable (kept the same for every trial) and ONE measured variable from the ‘Runny Honey’ experiment.

answers.content: Control variable: length of the tray (distance travelled).   Measured variable: time taken for each liquid to reach the finish line.
answers.explanation: Other valid control variables include amount of liquid, angle of tray, or surface material.

questions.question: Draw and label the experimental set-up you used to test viscosity, including the start line, finish line, three liquids, and the direction of movement.

answers.content: Drawing contains: clear tray/plate outline (1 mark); labelled start & finish lines (1 mark); at least three different liquids indicated (1 mark); arrow or description showing flow direction (1 mark).
answers.explanation: Assess using the rubric.

questions.question: When any state of matter is heated it generally _______.

answers.content: expands
answers.explanation: Heating gives the particles more energy so they move further apart, increasing the volume.

answers.content: contracts
stays the same size
disappears

questions.question: In the ‘Amazing Self-Inflating Balloon’ demonstration, the balloon inflated in hot water because:

answers.content: the air inside the bottle expanded and pushed into the balloon
answers.explanation: Heating the trapped air increased its volume and pressure, forcing it into the balloon.

answers.content: water flowed into the bottle and blew up the balloon
the air inside the bottle contracted
the rubber of the balloon expanded on its own

questions.question: Explain why a glass bottle that is filled with water may crack or shatter after being placed in a freezer overnight.

answers.content: Water expands when it freezes; the increased volume exerts pressure on the glass until it breaks.

questions.question: Under the same rise in temperature, which state of matter usually expands the most?

answers.content: gases
answers.explanation: Gas particles are far apart and move freely, so a temperature rise produces a large change in volume.

answers.content: liquids
solids
all expand equally

questions.question: What is thermal shock and how did it cause the glass jug in the video to shatter when cold water was poured onto the hot glass?

answers.content: Thermal shock is stress produced by a sudden, uneven temperature change; the outside of the hot glass cooled and contracted quickly while the inside stayed hot, creating stress that cracked the glass.

questions.question: Expansion joints are added to bridges primarily to:

answers.content: allow the bridge materials to expand and contract safely with temperature changes
answers.explanation: They prevent bending or cracking by giving the structure space to change length.

answers.content: collect and drain rainwater
decorate the roadway
add extra weight for stability

questions.question: Why does running a tight metal lid under hot water often make the jar easier to open?

answers.content: The metal lid heats up and expands slightly, loosening its grip on the glass jar.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple liquid-in-glass thermometer. Use arrows to show and explain how the liquid moves when the thermometer is warmed and when it is cooled.

answers.content: Student drawing shows bulb, liquid column, scale; arrow up for heating (expansion) and arrow down for cooling (contraction).
